Tweet text: @rmflight @FedeBioinfo I reckon you should go distill than a bookdown. The "listing" feature makes it easier to list your posts in distill

@rmflight @FedeBioinfo You might need to upgrade the theme if Hugo introduces breaking changes. You can choose not to update Hugo as well but I can't resist wanting the latest ‚ú®
Also components of distill site is easier for me to manage since it's R/HTML/CSS/JS, while Hugo is in Go (which idk)

@Sevvandik I was thinking of migrating last year when Hugo Academic became wowchemy, but the main reason was because I updated blogdown and I got an error serving my site. There's too many parts to Hugo, I wanted something more simple. Hugo is in Go lang, so debugging was harder for me too
@andreashandel @Sevvandik Perhaps! :)

@FedeBioinfo Yeah I got fed up with what happened to wowchemy and I didn't like the direction it was going. If you know how to make Rmd site already, it's not too much overhead learning it. There are some cost in migrating and setting up which I hope it's worthwhile in the end

I've decided to migrate my site (still under üöß) from hugo academic (now wowchemy ü§®) via blogdown to distill & I can tell I prefer it.

@LisaDeBruine df[ , 1, drop = TRUE] will always be a vector (works for tibble too). Same issue also happens for matrix and drop argument works the same way there too.
 
I'd be more inclined to go for df[[1]] though if you know you want to extract a single column.
@zentree I'm enjoying the discussion thanks üòä

@zentree Complementary in the sense that most design pkgs focus on randomisation or algorithms to find the most efficient design. That's one of the step in edibble grammar which you can replace with your fav design pkg https://t.co/KqjF0YE4PS

@zentree One thing to keep in mind that re-running an experiment is generally expensive. Re-doing an analysis is generally cheap/easy. You want to carefully plan out lest you end up wasting precious resources. edibble tries to get users to think and is complementary to other design pkgs

@zentree If you want something quick, there is some support for generating named designs (https://t.co/MHKHFuKjqf) with each accompanied with edibble code.

This is similar arg with plot/qplot vs. ggplot though. Quick is not the point, but rather how you express what u want can guide u

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb @bolkerb sounds right. You can use `agricolae` for LSD. Maybe like below

library(dplyr)
period <- 1:3 # 3 x 3-year periods, 3 site
agricolae::design.lsd(trt = period)$book %>% 
  rename(
         id = plots,
         site = col, 
         year = row) %>% 
  arrange(period, year)

@visnut Close! RCBD and split-plot can have the same structure but treatment allocation is different (with RCBD being `allocate_trts(style:exam ~ student)` in edibble)

@antoine_fabri @rstatstweet I chose with_value since it read more like a sentence "expect variables exam mark to be numeric with value between 0 and 100", and the package is supposed to be the _grammar_ of exp design, so I want to stick with the readability side 
(Appreciate your comments though, thanks!)

@antoine_fabri @rstatstweet Ah that's to do with the tibble output automatically chopping it since my computer screen is not wide enough. If you have a wide screen it wouldn't have chopped it

I'm using openxlsx to do the writing and validation so it's already it's own package üôÇ

Also if you'd like to know more, I'll be talking about this (in Japanese, though) at the next @TokyoRCommunity 

https://t.co/FcU908Y9qb

edibble still has many shortcomings but hopefully will improve with your feedback üîß What sort of experimental design is common in your own field?

Finally, thank you to the tidyverse team who do such amazing work!! edibble would not have been possible without tidyverse üíê

(12/)

By the way, in practice designing experiments is a lot of back and forth with the domain expert. 

You can add contextual information which gets exported to the excel sheet but also it shows up in the print out of intermediate constructs of the design. 

(11/) https://t.co/JufUSS1yCt

Also notice that there are two levels of observational units? You're recording information on students _and_ classroom. Students are nested in classroom. Rather than duplicating classroom information in one big spreadsheet, the classroom is separated into its own sheet.

(10/) https://t.co/tAjKiRtmHU

And for numerical values, if you try to enter values outside of the expected range, it'll give you an error. 

Minimising data entry errors can help you heaps in the downstream analysis!

(9/) https://t.co/W5mIqc3nFH

Well, in the exported excel sheet, the variables you are recording are constraint according to the values you set. Gender was set to be a factor with levels specified. In the exported file, the cell now has a drop-down menu. 

(8/) https://t.co/HGSXLS8Uuh

Or you may want to port the resulting data frame from other pkg to make use of data entry validation feature in edibble.

Remember that very first design you saw? You can specify what variables you are going to record (e.g. response) & you can set expected values. But why?

(7/) https://t.co/ad5f2uP7OA

But you have your own favourite software to generate experimental designs or edibble can't do the same randomisation process as other software? You might still find it useful to generate the nested structure with edibble and port the table to other software. 

(6/) https://t.co/SUaDZzSt07

But named experimental designs are convenient! edibble can make classical named designs (currently limited) with the declarative code of specifying the design printed out that you can copy-and-paste 

(5/) https://t.co/d7TUgsNGFb

An analogy is base graphics & grammar of graphics. Which one promotes you to think about the relation between graphics?

(4/) https://t.co/Mkrmxy70r8

edibble builds experiments designs by declaring experimental components rather than functions named after named experimental designs. The previous design is a type of split-plot design!

(3/) https://t.co/1iGbr0EwgD

In this experiment, you are interested in testing 2 different teaching styles (flipped or traditional) & how different types of exams affect student marks (take home, open book, or closed book).  There are 4 classes, 30 students in each class. How do you allocate treatments?
(2/) https://t.co/EJunojYuSQ

Without giving you any context, what sort of experiment do you think the code is constructing? 

I'd like to start getting ready for the CRAN release for edibble #rstats package so your feedback is appreciated!

@antoine_fabri I think the idea is pretty neat but in practice, a lot of care is needed. Like if you rename a column, you'll have to update the expressions that use that column, and R has a number of ways to rename column names. So as you say painful for robust implementation!
